The draft will be discussed in its present form by the ministerial Committee on Local Government Reorganisation on Monday,19th January; and as scon as possible thereafter a final version of itwill be circulated to the Cabinet for consideration at their meeting onThursday, 22nd January.Ce A0Pvc C0Storey's Gate, S. W.l016th January, 1970 DRMjT J7HITE PAPERLOCAL IN ENG-LANDContentsThe new structureThe work of the main authorities the mapLocal Councils and decentralisedadministrationRelations between central and localgovernmentTaxationElectoral, constitutional and relatedmattersBringing the new system into operationConclusion INFIDENTIALDRAFT WHITE PAPERLOCAL GOVERNMENT IN ENGLANDI - THE NEW STRUCTUREIntroduction1. In the early years of this Parliament the Government came to theconclusion that fundamental reviews of the structure, organisation and machinery of government at various levels were already overdue. Amongthe institutions which required review in this way was local government2o Accordingly Royal Commissions with wide terms of reference4 were established under the chairmanship of Lord Redcliffe-Maud andLord Wheatley respectively to review the organisation of local govern-ment in England and Scotland while the Government went ahead with itsown review of local government in Wales.3. Even while the Royal Commissions were at work, a further step wastaken with the appointment of the Commission on the Constitution, whoseterms of reference^ charged it, in considering the subjects of its owninquiry, to have regard to developments in local government organisation.*To consider the structure of Local Government in England, outsideGreater London, in relation to its existing functions; and to make recommendations for authorities and boundaries, and for functions andtheir division, having regard to the size and character of areas inwhich these can be most effectively exercised and the need to sustaina viable system of local democracy; and to report.^"To examine the present functions of the central legislature and government in relation to the several countries, nations and regions of the United Kingdom:To consider, having regard to developments in local government organisation and in the administrative and other relationships betweenthe various parts of the United Kingdom and to the interests of the prosperity and good government of our people under the Crown, whether any changes are desirable in those functions or otherwise in present constitutional and economic relationships:To consider, also, whether any changes are desirable in the constitutional and economic relationships between the United Kingdom and theChannel Islands and the Isle of Man. CONFIDENTIALif0 This White Paper deals with the reorganisation of local governmentin England. The next steps in Scotland and Wales arc referred to inparagraphs "15-17 below.5. The great mass of evidence to the Redclif fe-J4aud Commission showedhow extensive a body of opinion, both inside and outside local govcrn-raont, considered that fundamental changes were required. The piecemealmethods that the Local Government Commission for England had been forced to adopt under the Local Government Act 1953 were widelyreorganised as inadequate.6. When the report of the Royal Commission (Cmnd. 40^0) v/as published on 11th June 19^9, the Prime Minister gave it a warm welcome, payingtribute, in which the Leader of the Opposition joined, to the commissions exhaustive studies and comprehensive recommendations.The Prime Minister announced the Government's acceptance of the three main principles of the report - that a major rationalisation of localgovernment was called for, that there should be a very marked reductionin the number of units with executive responsibility and that theanachronistic division between town and country should be ended. he made it plain, however, that the Government was not committed to the detailed proposals in the report and thorough consultations were held to discover the views of all interested parties on the new structurerecommended by the Commission. The comments made during consultationshave confirmed what was already clear from the evidence to theCommission - the overwhelming support for far-reaching reforms thatwill fit local government for the daunting tasks in front of it.7. Not many commentators agreed \tfith the report down to the lastdetail: but acceptance of its principles was widespread. On virtuallyevery point of substance on which some commentators disagreed with thereport there were others who expressed equally strong agreement. an account of the opinions received is given in Appendix A. 80 The Government have carefully weighed all the views expressed inthe consultations, the proposals put forward with such force and con-viction in the dissenting memorandum by Mr. Senior and the results oftheir own studies. There is no "right solution" to the problem of reorganisation. Whatever solution is chosen must sacrifice some tilingsin the interest of others and changes in it will be needed from time totime to keep it up to date with the changing pattern of where peoplelive and work and with technological advance. It is the Government1sconclusion that in its essentials the report of the Royal Commissionstands. The Commission described the processes of thought which ledthem to their choice of structure. Their chain of reasoning, set outnotably in paragraphs 6 to 16 of their report, is reproduced for con-venience in Appendix B. In the Government's judgment, the Commission'sproposals provide a much better basis for reorganisation than any ofthe alternatives and though the Government's conclusions differ fromthe Commission's on certain points, they are not points of principle.The- Commission' s_ jaroposals9. The Commission proposed that(a) the greater part of England should be organised in "unitary areas" with populations not much less than 250,000 and not much more than 1,000,000 in which a single authority would exercise all local government functions;(b) exceptionally, places where planning, transportation anddevelopment need authorities which would be too large forother services should be organised as "metropolitan areas"in which functions would be divided between two tiers of authority;(c) in the unitary areas, and in the metropolitan areas wherethe inhabitants wanted them, there should be "local councils"the most important function of which would be to make knownthe views of local communities on any matters affecting them; V-i?\J*iiX y 1 Ihj^^ i^I 1 8^%&ai(d) the unitary areas and metropolitan areas should be groupedin 8 provinces, each with a provincial council consisting ofmembers elected by the main authorities and some co-optedmembers, their chief task being to create a broad framework for the exercise of the main authorities1 operationalresponsibilities.The Government's general jljsws10. The Government's detailed proposals differ from the Commission'sonly on the distribution of functions in areas where there are to be two tiers, the application of the Commission's structure in two partsof England and certain important aspects of the proposals for local councils. These differences are described at the appropriate points in the following parts of this paper.11. Unless local government is organised to fit the needs of thefuture, and in particular organised in units that are large enough to match the technical and other requirements of the services that theyadminister, its power will diminish. The Government intend that thepresent reorganisation should give local government noro power and influence.12. The choice of structure is not one of degree, of how far to go.It is a choice between a structure composed of largo units - unitaryones, wherever conditions make this feasible - and something more closely resembling what exists today. The Government1s consideredchoice is the former.13. The Government advisedly speak about the needs of the future, notmerely the present. The new organisation cannot start functioningearlier than the spring of 197^: the interval is needed for elaboratingthe scheme and preparing legislation; for Parliamentary considerationof the legislation; and for the process of transition. The new authorities will not reach their full efficiency until some years after they assume power. The new structure must be designed to lastin essentials till the year 2000 and beyond.Pro vine ejs14. The Government intend to keep an open mind at present on the pro-posals for organising local authorities in provinces. Machinery willbe needed to carry out at the provincial level tasks of the kind theCommission described, but though the Government has always made clearthat the reorganisation of local government proper will not be delayed until the findings of the Commission on the Constitution arc known,the work of that Commission has an obvious bearing on the form thatany provincial machinery should take. As foreshadowed by the PrimeMinister in his statement to the House on 11th June 1969, theGovernment has decided that it would be premature to reach conclusions on this subject until the Commission has reported. The essentialcorollary of this decision is that, in the meantime, the valuable workof the Regional Economic Planning Councils, to which tho government attach great importance, must be carried forward. Arrangements will bemade for developing the co-operation of the Economic Planning Councilswith local authorities and Standing Conferences or other associations of local authorities for planning purposes, in order to ensure thattheir aims and policies are increasingly co-ordinated and harmonisedwith each other.Scotland andL Wales15* In considering the reorganisation of local government, some factoroperate equally throughout Great Britain. For example, where towns andthe countryside have become a unity for the activities of local govern-ment, the organisation should not divide them. On the other hand the differences in the geography and history of the three countries make itwrong to try to force local government organisation into the same mouldfor each. 16. Consultations are taking place on the report of the BoyalCommission on Local Government in Scotland, under the chairmanship ofLord V/heatley (Cmnd. Vl^O). A White Paper on the future structure oflocal government in Scotland will be laid before Parliament in the spring.17. The Government published its proposals for the reorganisation oflocal government in Wales in the White Paper of July 1967. After theRoyal Commissions on Local Government in England and Scotland had reported, the Secretary of State for Wales decided to make a further review of the geographical counties of Glamorgan and Monraouth to seeif a satisfactory pattern could be worked out which would avoid thecontinued divisions between county boroughs and administrative counties.He will report his conclusions shortly. 180 The Government accept the Commissions conclusion on theadvantages of making a single authority responsible for all services in a particular area, wherever geographical and other factors make this possible. Successful local government will depend increasinglyon the ability of authorities to co-ordinate a wide range of functions in furtherance of the objectives they have set out to achieve, andon developing links between services- Adoption of the unitary systemwherever possible will make local government stronger, more efficient and more comprehensible to the public *19. Modern conditions require that the unitary areas should cover both town and country. The point is not that the interests of town and country are identical but that they are complementary and that theirsocial and economic interdependence has increased to a point where onlya single authority responsible for both can undertake the planneddevelopment of the main local government services to the maximumadvantage of the dwellers in town and country. The Government agreebroadly with the Commission about the size of the unitary areas,although a few of the unitary areas proposed by the Commission may on further examination prove to be on the small side20. It will, of course, be necessary to choose a suitable genericterm for the "unitary areas" as well as for the "metropolitan areas":for the time being the Government use in this paper the terms chosen by the Commission as a matter of convenience in discussion, and not as permanent labelso The Government also use the term "main authorities"in the same sense as the Commission, to describe the unitary authoritiesmetropolitan authorities and metropolitan district councils, i.e. allauthorities except the local councils.The Metropolitan Areas21 o The Government agree that in some parts of the country therequirements of land-use planning and transportation point towards unitary areas with much larger populations than are necessary orreasonable for some other services; and that a two-tier system is inthese circumstances unavoidable.22o The Commission's proposed division of functions between the twotiers in metropolitan areas is sot out in Appendix Co The government propose that in such areas education should be entrusted to the uppertier authority. The Commission preferred the lower tier authorityso that education could be administered by the same authorities asthe personal social services concerned with children., There are,however, powerful arguments on the other side. In general it is truethat an authority which can command large resources, particularly inspecialised manpower, can provide a more efficient education service.In particular the metropolitan areas contain heavy concentrations ofinstitutions for further and higher education- These forms of educationmake exceptional demands on the resources of the administering authority and involve the provision of facilities which have wideimplications for the "environmental services", planning, transportationand development, Since students are mobile and catchment areasextensive, wide coordination is needed; It is true that the problemof cooperation between the education authority and the lower tierauthorities in connection with the children of families needingspecial help remains, but this need be no greater than the problemof cooperation between lower tier authorities in education matters which the Commission^ solution would generate., The choice is a difficult one, and the Government have weighed with great care thearguments in the Commission^ report and that of the Seebohm Committee*for entrusting education to the same authorities as the other personal services, but they have concluded in favour of making education theresponsibility of the metropolitan authorities.*Report of the Committee on Local Authority and Allied personal social Services, 1969 (Cmnd. 3703) CONFIDENTIAL23. The transfer of education to the metropolitan authorities means,in the Government's view, that they should be the rating authoritiesin metropolitan areas, as the bulk of expenditure there will fall on them.2^. The Commission^ proposals about housing have given the Governmentsome hesitation. The Commission proposed that responsibilities shouldbe divided as follows:Metropolitan authority Metropolitan district council(a) metropolitan housing policy (i) building (within framework of metropolitan policy)(b.) building in the interests ofthe metropolitan area as a whole (ii) house management(c) building to ensure fulfilment (iii) all other housing powersof planning policies(d) policy for selection of tenants(e) metropolitan rent policy the Commission were clearly right in believing that the functionslisted on the left must be carried out by the authorities responsiblefor planning, transportation and development: they are among themost important ways in which planning is put into practical effect.It is arguable that the other housing functions should be entrusted to the same authorities, to avoid division of responsibility. TheGovernment's conclusion is that the Commission are right in believing that the drawbacks of this division are outweighed by the advantages of giving the responsibilities on the right to authorities responsiblefor the relevant personal social services; and they agree in principlev/ith the Commission' s proposals. However, they also believe that when these proposals are translated into statutory terms the power of themetropolitan authorities to undertake building should be widely drawn,and should include power to supplement or re inforce the housebuildingprogrammes of the district councils.25. The Government agree generally with the Commission^ proposals about how other responsibilities should be distributed in the metropolitan areas. All statutory planning and transport powers mustbelong, as the Commission recommended, to the metropolitan authorities.There are one or two instances, however, where the Government wish toconsider the precise allocation of functions in more detail.The National Health Service26. The Royal Commission welcomed the proposal in the Green Paper*,published while they were still at work, that the administration ofthe hospital, general practitioner and local health services should bebrought together. The Commission made plain that they had not takenevidence on the subject, but suggested that consideration should begiven to unifying responsibility for the national health service withinthe new system of local government. They set out a number of arguments in favour of this course of action though they appreciated thefinancial and other difficulties.27. After full consideration the Government have decided that suchan arrangement would not be practicable. They endorse the Commission'view, however, that the unified health service and the local authoritypersonal social services must be closely co-ordinated, and agree withthe Commission that the health service should be reorganised on thebasis of the new main local authority areas. Details of theGovernment's revised proposals regarding the administration of the health services in England will be published shortly in a furtherGreen Paper.Special Cases28. The Government's conclusions about the services which theCommission dealt with under the heading of "special cases", such asthe police, are set out in Appendix D to this paper. These concern thework of both the unitary and the metropolitan authorities.*National Health Service: The Administrative Structure of the medical and Related Services in England and Wales. HMSO 1968. Ill - THE MAP29. The Commission proposed 58 unitary areas; and explained at theend of their report what places each would include and why. Theysimilarly set out proposals for 3 "metropolitan areas" with two tiersof administration, on Merseyside, in South-East Lancashire and Cheshireand in the West Midlands; and for 20 districts in them,, TheCommission's map showing the 58 unitary and 3 metropolitan areas isreprinted at the end of this paper.30. It is convenient to give the Government's conclusions about two-tier areas first.Two-tier Areas31. The Government agree, as they have said above, that where,because of concentrations of population, the environmental group of services - that is, planning, transport and development - ought to bedealt with on a large scale, the ideal of a single authority for all services must be given up. There must be a large authority for some services and several smaller ones for the rest.32. They agree that the three "metropolitan areas" described by theCommission ought to be organised in this way. They recognise what itwill mean for cities and towns in these areas which have throughout their history been accustomed to manage all their own local affairs.They regret that in the West Midlands it means reorganising an area which underwent reorganisation only a few years.ago. However, theenvironmental services above all need.the comprehensive and imaginativedevelopment which only a single authority can provide; and joint work by several different authorities is inevitably coupled with too large a part being played by central government. For the same reason, theGovernment are satisfied that the Commission were right to draw wideboundaries for these areas, taking in parts of the surrounding country,though the actual line of the boundaries needs to be considered in thenext stage of consultations, in common with other boundary lines. 33. The Government have reached the conclusions that in addition tothe three areas proposed by the Commission the following additionaltwo-tier areas should bo created:-West YorkshireAn area formed by combining the Commission's areas No. 7(Bradford), No, 8 (Leeds), No. 9 (Halifax), No. 10 (Huddersfield)and No. 11 (Mid-Yorkshire).South HampshireAn area formed by combining the Commissions areas No. 57(Southampton and South Hampshire) and No. 58 (Portsmouth,South-East Hampshire and the Isle of Wight).3^. The Commission made it clear that their choices were reachedafter considerable study: and they set out (pages 77, 79? 193i 296and 297) their reasons for not including the two areas that theGovernment now propose. The Government's reasons for differingare these.35- Though the population of West Yorkshire is not so concentratedas the population in the Commission's three areas, the Government are convinced that the area needs to be planned as a whole. Between now and the end of the century it will see great changes. Its industries are changing and its towns are being redeveloped. The encouragement and location of new employement needs to be considered in conjunctionwith the solutions to the bad housing conditions from which so muchof West Yorkshire suffers. This process of transformation, and changesin communications to fit it, ought to be planned and supervised by asingle authority. Secondly, it is a part of the country whereeducation can be managed by a single authority with great advantage.Its boundaries would embrace the greater part of the present area ofthe West Riding in addition to the county boroughs of Bradford, Leeds,Halifax and Huddersfield, and, since the Government propose, in CONFIDENTIALmetropolitan areas, to entrust education to the metropolitanauthorities, it would provide an education authority of great strength in this part of the country,360 In South Hampshire, the Government's difference from theCommission is, they believe, essentially one of timing. This area is growing exceptionally fast; there is every reason to expect itsgrowth to continue, and indeed to accelerate . The Government believethat there is a real danger of mistakes being made and opportunitiesmissed unless a single authority can from the outset of the new localgovernment system have full responsibility for planning the developmentof the whole area.37o The Government have reached the firm conclusion, after studyingall the possibilities, that the three original areas and the two nowadded are the only ones where a two-tier system should be adopted inthe reorganisation which is about to take place. There are other areas, such as Mid-Lancashire, which the Commission found a difficultpart of the country, where two tiers may well be needed in the courseof time, but whether and when this happens will depend on developmentsthat cannot now be accurately foreseen. It is the Government'intention, however, to ensure that subsequent changes in the reorganised structure of local government in any particular area canbe me.de without the need for a further ActoDistricts in two-tier areas380 The Government do not think that allocation of responsibilityfor education to the metropolitan authorities calls for a differentpattern of districts from that proposed by the Commission. They takethe view that districts of the general size proposed by theCommission will be necessary, in the circumstances of the metropolitanareas, for effective housing and social service authorities. Therewill of course be full opportunity to comment on the boundaries ofthe metropolitan districts during the consultations which will takeplace on the boundaries of the new local government areas.CONFIDENTIAL 39. The Government will also seek advice about the division of thetwo additional areas. Their present opinions are as follows:-West YorkshireThere should be five districts, corresponding to the fiveunitary areas proposed by the Commission. These are workablesub-divisions, and their sizes are suitable.South HampshireThere should be three districts. One would be theCommission's area No. 57; the second the Commission's areaNo. 58, less the Isle of Wight; and the third the Isle of Wight,the last being an exceptionally small district justified byexceptional circumstances.The unitary areas^0. Leaving aside detailed boundary questions, on which severalauthorities have already tabled suggestions, the Government's presentopinion is that the unitary areas proposed by the Commission, reducedto 51 in number by the additional tv/o-tier areas, are of the right size and shape. However, the Government do not think that the door shouldbe closed on the possibility of joining some of the unitary areastogether, if in the course of further consultation with theauthorities concerned strong arguments for doing so emerge. On theother hand they see no instance of a unitary area which could be divided into two without making one or both of the parts too small,or dividing tasks which ought to be dealt with as unities. IV. THE LOCAL-COUNCILS AND DECENTRALISED ADMINISTRATIONif1. There has been much public discussion and questioning of the concept of local councils. Further work is required to convert theCommission's proposals into a form that will make local councils an effective part of the local government structure, as the Government issure that they will prove to be.The purpose..,of--lpc-al councils42. The Royal Commission recommended that in unitary areas, andwherever they were wanted in metropolitan areas, there should be local councils, elected at the outset for the areas of existing county boroughs, boroughs, urban districts and parishes. Local councils wouldnot have a statutory duty to provide any services but they would voicethe opinions and wishes of their inhabitants, be consulted by themain authorities when any proposal particularly affected them and havethe power to spend money on improving what the Commission called"the amenity raid convenience" of their areas. The Commission also proposed that the larger local councils should be able to play a part,according.to their resources end with the agreement of the unitaryauthority, in some main local government services.43. There has been a considerable body of opinion in support of theview that if there are to be unitary authorities then elected bodiesat a more local level are also necessary. The Commission's detailed proposals have, however, been criticised for not giving local councilsa good enough job to attract people of calibre. They have also been attacked for apparently suggesting that the local council for alarge city, probably the headquarters of a unitary authority, shouldhave the same functions as the council of a small parish. Ijif. The proposed organisation of local government involves asubstantial reduction.in the number of people who can serve thecommunity as members of authorities with the duty of administeringservices. There is admittedly here a danger of "remoteness", of lossof contact between the citizen and the authority, and a risk ofincreasing the tendency for people to think of government of all kinds,however democratically based, as separate from themselves. this tendency is strengthened if fewer people have the opportunity ofknowing their elected representatives as individual persons.k% These risks are inherent in organising local government in unitsthat correspond \vith the realities of an increasingly mobile society;they cannot be wholly avoided but they can be reduced. A necessarycounterpart of the inevitable concentration of responsibility for services in many fewer authorities must be the inclusion, in the new structure, of elected councils to look after the special interests ofparticular places and serving a different purpose from the countyborough, borough end district councils of today.^6. In modern society, projects needed for the general goodincreasingly have significant local effects. The detailed ways inwhich they are worked out can make- a great difference to the benefit or harm they do to particular localities, and the people who livethere must have an effective means of making known their reactionsand wishes.4?. The Government accordingly agree with the Royal Commission that local councils embody a principle that is basic to the new system oflocal government. They consider, however, that changes are needed inthe Commission's detailed proposals to meet points which have arisen inthe consultations which the Government have had with interested parties and during further consideration inside Government. Their fmictions48. In the Government's view, the Royal Commission were right tosay that local councils should have the power to do things, at theirown expense, which would make their areas more attractive and convenient to live in; the Commission indicated some of the things that local councils might provide and these are listed in Appendix E. Localauthorities - including parish councils - already have a general power,too, enabling them to spend money for the benefit of their areas andtheir inhabitants. This is a useful provision and local councils will need a similar power to spend money on improving the appearance oftheir areas and on projects of local benefit. The extent of thispoxtfer will be considered during the discussions with the local authority associations referred to in paragraphs 68 and 69 below.4-9. The revenues of local councils would come from rates leviedin their areas (the demands being sent out by the main authorities atthe same time as their own demands). As the Commission say, their capital expenditure would have to be found within the.total allottedfor the main authority's area: this means, of course, that the consentof the main authority would be necessary. The Green Paper mentionedin paragraph 63 will discuss the financial arrangements between mainauthorities and local councils. The Government think that somerecurrent expenditure by local councils, for example on such revenue-earning activities as providing seaside marinas, should also requirethe consent of the main authorities, since it can.be large enough tobe economically significant. They do not,however, think it necessarythat there should be an equivalent of the limitation in terms of rateyield which applies to parishes at present. 30. The Government do not agree with the suggestion made by theRoyal Commission that the larger local councils should themselves play a part in the provision of major services. The division ofresponsibility would be harmful to the services concerned and would cause confusion, particularly as the position would vary from one part of a unitary area, to the next.51. There must be a clear obligation on the main authorities to consult local councils if they are to be able to bring the opinions of their communities to bear on proposals that particularly affectthem. The Government will consider, with the help of the localauthority associations, how the right of local councils to be consulted should be defined, ^hey are inclined at present to thinkthat rigid, formal arrangements may defeat their own objects.32. Local councils should have the opportunity of appointing membersof school governing bodies, management committees for old people1shomes, and as wide a variety as possible of other bodies.53- The Government believe that another important function can beadded, namely, that members of local councils should serve ondistrict committees of the unitary authorities; and they have accepted the suggestion made by the County Councils' Association andothers that the reconciliation of functional efficiency with localparticipation will bo assisted by the decentralisation of administra-tion from the unitary authorities to such committees. This will beprovided for in the reorganisation legislation. District committees would be committees of the unitary authority and would be staffed bythat authority's officers. Members of local councils would.serve on them as of right: they would be chosen by the local, councils, not co-opted by the main authority. What proportion of the committees would come from local councils needs more study; but as the committees would be committees of the main authority they would be bound by theauthority's policies, and the authority could override a decision VtfV/ro r I UEIN E IALthey thought contrary to their policy. Tne Government look ondistrict committees as on important concomitant of the concept oflocal councils, and will examine in detail what range of localgovernment functions would he appropriate for decentralisedadministration hy them. In the planning field, control of development is suitable for decentralised administration of this kind.Their boundariesjk. The Government agree with the Commission that on practicalgrounds alone, local councils must be based at the start on the areasof existing local authorities. It would not be possible to definenew areas for local councils at the same time as carrying out the radical reorganisation of the authorities responsible for services.The Government think, however, that new areas for local councils should be worked out as soon as possible after the main reorganisation,without waiting for five years as the Commission suggested. Thereshould be no attempt to impose a uniform pattern, and full regard should be paid to the wishes of the local inhabitants.55* In general, there should be local councils throughout the wholeof a unitary area. Most parishes will no doubt remain as they are now and so, too, will most urban districts and boroughs, though theGovernment would welcome voluntary amalgamations of parishes and clsoof urban areas that are adjacent to each other and are now adminis-tered by separate councils. The Government would favour, too, someamalgamations of smell towns with their immediately surroundingcountryside. But the main problems are posed, not at this levelof size, but by towns with populations of over 100,000. Clearly, theinhabitants of a great city do not constitute a community in thesame sense as those of a small town but the inhabitants of somesizeable towns may well do so; and a resort town, for example, may wish to spend appreciable sums on local attractions that are of concern to the whole toivn, not only to parts of it. CONFlDiNYEAL56. The towns where the headquarters of the main authorities arelocated will be a special case, where special arrangements may benecessary.57. The Government will discuss with the local authority associationsthese end other questions that arise in creating a pattern of areasadapted to the purposes that local councils will serve in the new system, including the Commission's proposal that local councils should be set up in metropolitan areas where people want them.58. The Government incline to the view that in a large town it willhave to be for the existing elected council to decide whether thetown should continue to be represented by a single local council orwhether it should be divided among a number of local councils, eachrepresenting a community within the town. Where the latter occursthe local councils would be more in the nature of neighbourhood orcommunity councils. Such a development could bring a new anddifferent iype of elected representative into local government and could also prove an important experiment in participatory democracy.Neighbourhood councils would give the small communities that oftenreally make up towns the same kind of representation in the localgovernment system that people living in the country have had since189^ through their parish councils end would bring to an end, at this level too, the artificial distinction between town and country whichthe reorganisation of local government will abolish in theadministration of services. V., JgLATIOKS BETWEEN CENTRAL AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT59. The reorganisation of local government in larger units will by itself reduce the amount of work that central government has to do.Where central government performs a distributive function, forexample in allocating resources for capital investment, it willhave many fewer authorities to deal with than now - less than halfthe present number in the case of education and less than a tenthin the case of housing. Moreover, the reduction will make it easier for central and local government to exchange information, and sobring about a closer partnership and moro effective discussions, in financial and other matters.60. More fundamentally, the new pattern of authorities will open the way to giving local government much greater freedom than at present.Some technological changes - for example, bigger and better computers -make for increasing centralisation. It is therefore all the moreimportant to get rid of central controls that have become obsoleteand, still more, to take the fullest advantage of the opportunities for decentralisation which the new structure will create. Thefollowing paragraphs set out the Government's proposals about(i) financial controls, (ii) non-financial controls, (iii) controlover the way authorities manage their own internal affairs and (iv)a general power for the new local, authorities to take action for thebenefit of their areas and inhabitants.61 . The Government opened discussions with the local authority associations on the subject of controls in the light of the recommenda-tions of the Committee on the Management of Local Government. Theyhave more recently asked the associations to specify, in the furtherlight of the Commission^ report, the ways in which they think the discretion of local authorities should be enlarged after reorganisation. The associations' answers will help the government in studying the subjects dealt with below.Central, controls(i) Financial62. The most irksome form of central government control is controlover borrowing, which in practice takes the form of the Government'ssanction being needed for the great majority of capital projects.Central government must, as the Commission accepted, concern itself with total investment, with its allocation among the major servicesand with national standards in those services. However, control overborrowing in the form which it has taken under successive Governments,for many years past is more restrictive and laborious than it need be. The Government is at work, and will be seeking the help of localgovernment, on ways to improve the system, essentially by providingfor control through programmes, instead of more detailed methods,for the more important sectors of the major services; and by allowingconsiderable freedom of decision for local authorities over the restby way of an unallocated margin of expenditure. Indeed, as the PrimeMinister has announced, the Government are seeking moans of increasingthe discretion of local authorities even before local government isreorganised.63. This is only one part of the thorough-going review of localgovernment finance for which the reorganisation creates both thenecessity and the opportunity.. This review must comprehend, of course,taxation levied by local government, on which some conclusions ofthe Government are recorded below.. Before legislation is prepared,the Government wish to obtain the views of local authorities and others,which means setting out proposals in more detail than the commission were able to do or would be appropriate to the present paper. they intend at a suitable stage to publish a Green Paper dealing fully withcontrols and with taxation. Moreover, itbears on an objective which the Government are pursuing of reducingeffort spent by Government Departments and local authorities onaccounting transactions between them.(ii) Non^fIjmncial.65.
